sound.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: something that you hear, or what can be heard
sound.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: There were strange sounds coming from the next room.
She could hear the sound of voices.
sound.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: the sound produced by a television or radio programme, a film etc
sound.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: We apologize for the loss of sound during that report.
sound.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: the loudness of a television, radio, film etc
sound.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Turn the sound down a little, will you?
sound.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: the particular quality that a singer’s or group’s music has
sound.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: We’re trying to develop a harder, funkier sound.
sound.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: a narrow area of water that connects two larger areas of water
sound.translation[0].note_box[0].section: There was a loud creaking sound and the branch snapped.
The sound was so faint I wasn’t sure what it was at first.
The sound of the waterfall was deafening.
Suddenly from below came the unmistakable sound of gunfire.
I heard a strange sound coming from outside.
Suddenly she heard the familiar sound of the key being turned in the front door.
All seemed quiet, but for the distant sound of police sirens.
Now there were muffled sounds of movement.
There was an odd buzzing sound in her ears.
She heard the sound of a car starting.
The machine made a strange hissing sound.
He lay still and didn’t make a sound.
The sounds seemed to be coming from the study below.
I knew the sound of the horn would would carry for miles.
I listened until the sound had died away completely.
sound.translation[0].note_box[1].section: a high sound
squeak
a very short high sound or cry
I heard the squeak of his shoes on the tiled floor.
Annie gave a squeak of surprise.
creak
a long high sound that something makes when someone opens it, walks on it, sits on it etc – used especially about a door, wooden floor, bed, or stairs
the creak of floorboards
The door opened with a creak.
screech
a loud, long, unpleasantly high sound – used especially about someone’s voice, or about brakes, tyres etc
There was a screech of tyres followed by a bang.
She let out a screech of horror.
beep
a high electronic sound that a machine sends out, especially in order to attract someone’s attention
You’ll hear a bleep when the photocopier’s finished printing.
a quiet sound
hum
a quiet low continuous sound, especially from electrical equipment, traffic, an engine, or people’s conversation
The only sound was the faint hum of the air-conditioning unit.
He could hear the hum of distant traffic.
rustle
a continuous quiet sound from papers, leaves, or clothes when they rub together
She heard the rustle of dried leaves behind her.
the rustle of silk dresses
murmur
a quiet low continuous sound, especially from people’s voices that are far away
The murmur of voices died away.
They spoke in a low murmur.
rumble
a series of long low sounds, especially from big guns, traffic, or thunder
I heard a rumble of thunder.
the low rumble of a train approaching
made by a liquid
splash
the sound that a liquid makes when something hits it, or when it hits against another thing
She jumped into the pool with a big splash.
the splash of the waves against the rocks
gurgle
the low sound that water makes when it flows gently over or through something
the gurgle of a stream
She listened to the gurgle as the water drained out of the bath.
plop
the sudden short sound when something is dropped into a liquid
Kate dropped the ice into her glass with a plop.
made by air or gas
hiss
a continuous high sound when air or gas comes out of something
There was a hiss of steam from the coffee machine.
Workers reported hearing a loud hiss moments before the explosion.
made by an explosion, gun etc
bang
a short sudden loud noise made by a gun, bomb etc
There was a loud bang as the bomb exploded.
The firework went off with a bang.
boom
a very loud sound from an explosion, which you can hear for several seconds after it begins
The building exploded into rubble with a loud boom.
The boom of artillery fire echoed in the distance.
roar
a continuous very loud noise that gets louder and continues for a long time
The light was followed by the deafening roar of explosions.
the roar of the ship’s guns
made by things hitting other things
bang
a loud sound caused especially when something hard or heavy hits something else
I heard a loud bang and rushed out to see what had happened.
He slammed the door shut with a bang.
crash
a very loud sound caused when something hits something else, especially when damage is caused
The tray of dishes fell to the floor with a crash.
I heard an enormous crash outside our house, and I went to see what had happened.
thud
a quiet low sound made when a heavy object falls down onto surface
There was a dull thud as the box hit the floor.
His head hit the ground with a sickening thud.
thump
a dull loud sound made when a heavy object hits something else
There was a loud thump as Eddie threw Luther back against the wall.
clink
a short ringing sound made when two glass, metal, or china objects hit each other
the clink of champagne glasses
The clink of cutlery could be heard in the restaurant.
tinkle
the pleasant sound that is made by light pieces of glass or metal hitting each other repeatedly
He listened to the faint tinkle of cow bells in the distance.
jingle
the sound of small metal objects being shaken together
the jingle of her bracelets
the jingle of keys
rattle
a short repeated sound made when things hit against each other – used especially when part of something is loose and is hitting against something
There was a strange rattle coming from the engine.
the rattle of the trolley
sound.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: if something or someone sounds good, bad, strange etc, that is how they seem to you when you hear about them or read about them
sound.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: I’ll come over to Richmond and take you out for dinner. How does that sound (=used to ask someone what they think of your suggestion)?
The whole story sounded very odd.
$80 sounds about right for a decent hotel room.
Nick sounds like a nice guy.
It sounds to me as if he needs professional help.
It sounds like you had a good time on your trip.
sound.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: if a noise sounds like a particular thing, that is how it seems to you when you hear it
sound.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: To Thomas, her laugh sounded horribly like a growl.
I heard what sounded like fireworks.
The banging sounded as if it was coming from next door.
It sounds like the dog wants to be let out.
sound.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: if someone sounds tired, happy, sad etc, that is how they seem to you when you hear their voice
sound.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Are you okay? You sound tired.
Josie didn’t sound very keen when I spoke to her.
You sound as if you’ve got a cold.
She sounded like she’d been crying.
You sound just like my mother  (=the things you say, opinions you express etc are just like the things my mother says).
sound.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to publicly give a warning or tell people to be careful
sound.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: Several earlier studies had sounded similar warnings.
Now it is an American economist who is sounding the alarm.
I would, however, sound a note of caution.
sound.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: if something such as a horn or bell sounds, or if you sound it, it makes a noise
sound.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Sound your horn to warn other drivers.
She was unable to sound the alarm.
sound.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: to make the sound of a letter in a word
sound.translation[1].definitions[5].note: Sound is usually passive in this meaning
sound.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: to measure the depth of the sea, a lake etc
sound.translation[1].note_box[0].items[0: Sound is a linking verb This type of verb links the subject of the sentence with an adjective or noun
sound.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: sensible or good, and likely to produce the right results
sound.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The book is full of sound advice.
a man of great integrity and sound judgement
sound.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: someone who is sound can be depended on to make good decisions and give good advice
sound.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: He’s very sound on matters of law.
sound.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: someone who is sound is a good person and can be trusted – used especially by young people
sound.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: My mum’s sound. She’d never throw me out.
sound.translation[2].definitions[3].exam: a sound understanding of money and banking systems
He has a sound grasp of European history.
sound.translation[2].definitions[4].defi: in good condition and not damaged in any way
sound.translation[2].definitions[4].note: sound as a bell British English spoken (=in perfect condition)
sound.translation[2].definitions[5].note: sound as a bell British English spoken (=in perfect health)
sound.translation[2].definitions[6].defi: sound sleep is deep and peaceful
sound.translation[2].definitions[6].note: sound sleeper (=someone who always sleeps well)
sound.translation[2].note_box[0].section: He gave us some sound advice.
He was beginning to rely on her sound judgment.
Both these buyers have sound reasons for their choice.
Property is usually a sound investment.
The problems of industry will only be solved by sound economic policies.
Sometimes friendship is a sound basis for a good marriage.
The government encourages environmentally sound management of the countryside.
It was the ideologically sound thing to do.
